issues.description: The Lecture class in the solution repository declares its five attributes using snake_case (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, etc.) but the constructor and all getters/setters use camelCase names (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, etc.). This mismatch prevents the code from compiling and conflicts with the problem statement’s specified attribute names.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the fields in Lecture.java to camelCase (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors) so they match the constructor parameters and method implementations.

issues.description: In the solution implementation of Lecture.java, the five core attributes are declared using snake_case (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors), whereas the problem statement’s UML and tasks consistently refer to them using camelCase identifiers (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). This mismatch prevents students from mapping the specified attributes to the reference code and will cause compilation errors.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the attribute declarations in the solution to use camelCase to match the UML and problem description (e.g., change lecture_name to lectureName, number_of_inscribed_students to numberOfInscribedStudents, etc.).
